history.content: If you decide to take 186 and 189, just understand that grad schools may assume you had a lower grade in the other courses you took this semester. I would say this would be fine if the other courses are not related to the area of research you plan to apply to. Additionally, it really depends which field you want to apply to. Professor Shewchuck has mentioned that if you are considering a PhD in ML, you might as well take 189 for a grade to demonstrate your aptitude. I'm sure you've seen the post but here it is again from the 189 Piazza: https://piazza.com/class/k5n3zwlu8ly1he?cid=974.

children.subject: I'm mostly concerned with my GPA being 'sufficient' for PhD programs.

Gotcha, then in my opinion I think if you end up with above a 3.8 then take it for a grade, but if you are still within 3.75-3.79 range, I do not think it will make a big difference. You should probably take a look at the avg. GPAs of those accepted at the programs you want to apply to, and then make a decision. That said, the difference between 3.75 and a 3.8 can probably be outweighed by having solid letter of recs, research experience, and getting your name on a published paper. You can always focus on these, rather than stressing about your GPA. This is simply what I have observed as someone who is starting the 5th years MS program next fall. I do not have the anywhere near the top GPA that so many applicants have, but I was lucky enough to build rapport with my professors. While, this is not the same as applying to PhD programs, which have higher bars, I do know that the rest of your application matters a lot too. Hope this perspective helps!

Hi! Congratulations on being admitted to the 5th year MS!!! May I ask how do you feel about the process, is it very competitive? How much GPA do you need? Is it true that the best way to get in is to do research with a professor?  Thanks!!

<md>Not the same as Anon Mouse but I was also admitted as a 5th year MS. It is becoming more and more competitive for the program as more people are applying. GPA requirements are at least a 3.5 to apply and seems to be highly dependent on the research topic you chose and your particular advisor (ie, if you want to ML, you would need a higher GPA as a lot more people are looking to also do the same). Research with a professor is almost a hard requirement as they must commit to being your advisor during your year and you would need to complete some research project of some sort. 
As for the process overall, it was relatively smooth and was what I would expect from a normal application. However, they were pretty slow in getting responses back (possibly due to the current situation) but overall the application process wasn't to bad. </md>
@Anon Mouse, not really considering an ML PhD, and 186 and 189 are the only techs I'm taking (I'm PNP'ing my 2 breadths).

history.content: Sophomore here taking 186 and 189, on track for an A and an A/A-. I have roughly a 3.75 GPA so far, and I'm looking to apply to CS PhD programs after undergrad. I know that if I take all my classes DPN, grad schools won't care. What I'm thinking about is the tradeoff between boosting my GPA/reducing stress. Is it worth getting the small gpa increase, or is this diminishing returns in terms of grad schools not caring about my gpa?
history.subject: GPA for PhD
